Pregnant women are among the most endangered individuals by the symptoms of the Zika virus. 

 - The primary way that pregnant women get Zika virus is through the bite of an infected mosquito 

 - Less common but still relevant is the risk of contracting the virus through sexual intercourse 

 - A major concern regarding the infection of pregnant women is how easily the Zika virus can spread to her fetus 

 - Zika virus can be passed from a pregnant woman to her fetus during pregnancy and even at delivery 


Zika and microcephaly 

 - Since May 2015, Brazil has experienced a significant outbreak of the Zika virus; in recent months, Brazilian officials reported a concurrent increase in the number of babies born with microcephaly 

 - Recent studies show a direct correlation between the Zika virus and babies born with microcephaly
